abstract.p: Maryann Johanson letter on Nancy Hass's May 28 article holds formula for making blockbuster movies is simply matter of being creative, original, employing actual actors and not actively insulting intended audience (S)

block.p: As movies like ''The Sixth Sense,'' ''The Blair Witch Project'' and ''Gladiator'' have proven, the path to blockbusterdom is not as complicated as a quadratic equation: it's simply a matter of being creative, original, employing actual actors instead of pretty-faced movie stars, and not actively insulting the intended audience.

As movies like ''The Sixth Sense,'' ''The Blair Witch Project'' and ''Gladiator'' have proven, the path to blockbusterdom is not as complicated as a quadratic equation: it's simply a matter of being creative, original, employing actual actors instead of pretty-faced movie stars, and not actively insulting the intended audience.

Of course, turning out an intelligent, uncliched film isn't an easy thing to do. Here's a suggestion: instead of putting all your blockbuster eggs in one basket with yet another poorly written testosterone-fest or inane romantic comedy serving as a vanity project for a star with a $20 million paycheck, take that film's $100 million budget and give the money to 10 unknown writer-directors with fresh stories to tell and the hunger to tell them cheaply. If only one of the resulting films spawns a hot new writer, director or actor, the investment will pay off. And if more than one of those films is a hit, then you're ahead of the game.
